Notification.summary: The Notification interface of the {{domxref("Notifications API", "", "", "nocode")}} is used to configure and display desktop notifications to the user.

remarks.para: These notifications' appearance and specific functionality vary across platforms but generally they provide a way to asynchronously provide information to the user.

NotificationClick.summary:
The click event of the
interface fires when the user clicks on displayed .

remarks.para:
The default behavior is to move the focus to the viewport of the notification's related
browsing context.
If you don't want that behavior, call on the event object.

NotificationImage.summary:
NOTE Experimental The image read-only property of the
interface contains the URL of an image to be displayed as
part of the notification, as specified in the image option of the
constructor.

NotificationNotification.summary:
The Notification() constructor creates a new
object instance, which represents a user notification.

blockquote.para: Trying to create a notification inside the using the Notification() constructor will throw a TypeError. Use instead.

NotificationPermission.summary:
The permission read-only static property of the
interface indicates the current permission granted by the user for the current origin to
display web notifications.

remarks.para:
-Notifications API
-Using the Notifications API
-Permissions API
-Using the Permissions API

NotificationPermission.value: A string representing the current permission. The value can be:

NotificationError.summary: The error event of the interface fires when something goes wrong with a (in many cases an error preventing the notification from being displayed.)

NotificationDir.summary: The dir read-only property of the interface indicates the text direction of the notification, as specified in the dir option of the constructor.
NotificationDir.value:
A string specifying the text direction. Possible values are:
NOTEMost browsers seem to ignore explicit ltr and rtl settings, and just go with the browser-wide setting.

NotificationRequestPermission.summary: The requestPermission() static method of the interface requests permission from the user for the current origin to display notifications.

remarks.para: The method returns a that fulfills with a string indicating whether permission was granted or denied.

NotificationRequestPermission.returns:
A that resolves to a string with the permission picked by the user.
Possible values for this string are:The deprecated version of the method returns undefined.

NotificationClose.summary: The close event of the interface fires when a is closed.

NotificationVibrate.summary:
NOTE Experimental The vibrate read-only property of the
interface specifies a vibration pattern
for the device's vibration hardware to emit when the notification fires. This is
specified in the vibrate option of the
constructor.
NotificationVibrate.value: A vibration pattern, as specified in the Vibration API spec.

NotificationIcon.summary:
The icon read-only property of the
interface contains the URL of an icon to be displayed as
part of the notification, as specified in the icon option of the
constructor.

NotificationActions.summary: NOTE Experimental The actions read-only property of the interface provides the actions available for users to choose from for interacting with the notification.

remarks.para: The actions are set using the actions option of the second argument for the method and constructor.

blockquote.para: Browsers typically limit the maximum number of actions they will display for a particular notification. Check the static property to determine the limit.

NotificationActions.value: A read-only array of actions. Each element in the array is an object with the following members:

NotificationData.summary:
The data read-only property of the
interface returns a structured clone of the notification's
data, as specified in the data option of the
constructor.

remarks.para:
The notification's data can be any arbitrary data that you want associated with the
notification.

NotificationLang.summary:
The lang read-only property of the
interface indicates the language used in the notification,
as specified in the lang option of the
constructor.

remarks.para:
The language itself is specified using a string representing a language tag according to {{RFC(5646, "Tags for Identifying Languages (also known as BCP 47)")}}.
See the Sitepoint ISO 2 letter language codes page for a simple reference.

NotificationLang.value: A string specifying the language tag.

NotificationBadge.summary: The badge read-only property of the interface returns a string containing the URL of an image to represent the notification when there is not enough space to display the notification itself such as for example, the Android Notification Bar. On Android devices, the badge should accommodate devices up to 4x resolution, about 96 by 96 px, and the image will be automatically masked.

NotificationMaxActions.summary:
NOTE Experimental The maxActions read-only static property of the
interface returns the maximum number of actions supported by
the device and the User Agent. Effectively, this is the maximum number of elements in
array which will be respected by the User Agent.
NotificationMaxActions.value:
An integer number which indicates the largest number of notification
actions that can be presented to the user by the User Agent and the device.

NotificationTitle.summary:
The title read-only property of the
interface indicates the title of the notification, as
specified in the title parameter of the
constructor.

NotificationTag.summary:
The tag read-only property of the
interface signifies an identifying tag for the notification,
as specified in the tag option of the
constructor.

remarks.para:
The idea of notification tags is that more than one notification can share the same
tag, linking them together. One notification can then be programmatically replaced with
another to avoid the users' screen being filled up with a huge number of similar
notifications.

NotificationRequireInteraction.summary: The requireInteraction read-only property of the interface returns a boolean value indicating that a notification should remain active until the user clicks or dismisses it, rather than closing automatically.

blockquote.para: This can be set when the notification is first created by setting the requireInteraction option to true in the options object of the constructor.

NotificationClose.summary:
The close() method of the interface is used to
close/remove a previously displayed notification.

blockquote.para:
This API shouldn't be used just to have the notification
removed from the screen after a fixed delay since this method will also remove the
notification from any notification tray, preventing users from interacting with it
after it was initially shown. A valid use for this API would be to remove a
notification that is no longer relevant (e.g., the user already read the notification
on the webpage in the case of a messaging app or the following song is already playing
in a music app).

NotificationShow.summary: The show event of the interface fires when a is displayed.

NotificationBody.summary:
The body read-only property of the
interface indicates the body string of the notification, as
specified in the body option of the
constructor.

NotificationSilent.summary:
The silent read-only property of the
interface specifies whether the notification should be
silent, i.e., no sounds or vibrations should be issued regardless of the device
settings. This is controlled via the silent option of the
constructor.
NotificationSilent.value: A boolean value or null. If set to true, the notification is silent; if set to null (the default value), the device's default settings are respected.

NotificationRenotify.summary:
NOTE Experimental The renotify read-only property of the
interface specifies whether the user should be notified
after a new notification replaces an old one, as specified in the renotify
option of the constructor.
NotificationRenotify.value:
A boolean value. false is the default; true makes
the notification renotify the user.

NotificationTimestamp.summary:
NOTE Experimental The timestamp read-only property of the
interface returns a number, as
specified in the timestamp option of the
constructor.

remarks.para:
The notification's timestamp can represent the time, in milliseconds since 00:00:00 UTC
on 1 January 1970, of the event for which the notification was created, or it can be an
arbitrary timestamp that you want associated with the notification. For example, a
timestamp for an upcoming meeting could be set in the future, whereas a timestamp for a
missed message could be set in the past.

NotificationTimestamp.value: A number representing a timestamp, given as Unix time in milliseconds.
